title: How many high school students will play eleven-player football in the 2017/18 season?
preds: Rising numbers. Probably slightly more then last year.
I believe numbers will stabilize. Americans love Football and like every "shock" - it will go away and Kids will come back to Play Football.
Based my decision on a glance at the links provided and my sense that the rough downward trend should continue based on my own anecdotal evidence of attitudes of parents towards football.

“Ohio dad is first to sue youth helmet makers for death of son,” San Diego Union-Tribune, June 1, 2018. http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sports/sd-sp-dad-suing-helmet-makers-over-sons-death-20180601-story.html “The Mom Winning the Fight to Save Kids’ Brains From Football,” Daily Beast, June 15. https://www.thedailybeast.com/the-mom-winning-the-fight-to-save-kids-brains-from-football “Playing Youth Tackle Football Is Linked to Earlier Symptoms of Brain Disease,” TIME magazine, April 30. http://time.com/5258406/cte-youth-tackle-football/
There has to be some effect of the study, but some people will be very hard to convince as it means a change of lifestyle.

Parents, physicians and medical professionals, coaches and even youth football players are becoming more aware of the situation involving CTE brain-injury syndrome ... “Playing football young may mean earlier cognitive, emotional problems,” CNN, April 30, https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/30/health/youth-football-cte-study/index.html “Playing Youth Tackle Football Is Linked to Earlier Symptoms of Brain Disease,” TIME magazine, April 30. http://time.com/5258406/cte-youth-tackle-football/ “New study: Kids who play tackle football before the age of 12 get CTE symptoms 'much earlier,'” CBS Sports, May 1. https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/new-study-kids-who-play-tackle-football-before-the-age-of-12-get-cte-symptoms-much-earlier/ “Youth Tackle Football Linked to Earlier Onset of Cognitive and Emotional Symptoms in Athletes Diagnosed with CTE After Death,” Boston University School of Medicine, May 2. https://www.bumc.bu.edu/busm/2018/04/30/youth-tackle-football-linked-to-earlier-onset-of-cognitive-and-emotional-symptoms-in-athletes-diagnosed-with-cte-after-death/

A linear trend line for American football players participation during its decline since the 2010/11 season plots 2018/19 participation at 1,063,000 players. However, a moving average trend line plots the season to 1,058,000 players. Data from https://www.statista.com/statistics/267955/participation-in-us-high-school-football/ (which incorporates women's programs).
I made an error on my previous forecast.

I calculated my baseline using the following method:
1) Entered all participants by state from 2011-2017
2) Computed slope of linear best-fit line, using 2, 3, and all 7 years to account for different participation patterns by state. Using only 2 years of data, the total predicted was 1.034m. Using 3 years, total pred was 1.044m. With all 7 years, total pred was 1.051m.  I attempted to see if trends in youth tackle football could help me decide which sample set to use. A Washington Post article suggests that from 2008-2014, US youth participation in football dropped from 8.2 to 5.7% of all children, a relative decrease of 30% over 6 years! This is important because many of the youths are now high-school aged and kids who did not play organized football as children are probably less likely to play in high school as well. Factoring in widespread concerns about CTE, I believe 2018 participation will trend towards the lower side - more similar to last year's decline. https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/recruiting-insider/wp/2017/09/06/youth-sports-study-declining-participation-rising-costs-and-unqualified-coaches/?utm_term=.1241b812f69a
CTE news continues to alarm.  reductions in 17-18 will be higher than in 15-16
football will never go to zero. but smart schools and parents will advocate and make the switch to soccer.
Football is still the most popular sport in America, and there has been little recent publicity about CTE.

Last year there were 1059K total players playing 11 man football. It looks like participation has been dropping for the last few years, by 2k and 10k in the years before.  Given the growing social awareness of CTE and concussions in general, and the many other alternative sports that are out there, we should expect the trend to continue. This question is structured in a way that if the same 29k drop occurs, we would predict the lowest result amongst the answers. I think that this is a reasonable probability. Another interesting effect that could contribute - the drop in US population due to immigrants fears of current policies. Immigrants are a young population and would probably contribute further to the drop.
Parents and students continue to learn more about the issue and are exposed to reporting on examples of TBI in the news regularly.
Concussions have decreased enrollment probably a little but football is still loved by Americans.
HS football is a cultural phenom that will be highly resistant to change.

The news on CTE and head hits is not good.  Many responsible and intelligent parents will limit kids to flag football until around high school age, as recommended by some physicians. Related news and OSINT: “Former NFLers call for end to tackle football for kids,” CNN, Jan. 18. http://www.cnn.com/2018/01/18/health/nfl-no-tackle-football-kids/index.html “Repeated Hits to the Head — Not Concussions — May Cause CTE,” TIME magazine, Jan. 18. http://time.com/5107151/concussion-head-injury-chronic-traumatic-encephalopathy/ “Forget concussions. The real risk of CTE comes from repeated hits to the head, study shows,” Los Angeles, Times, Jan. 18. http://www.latimes.com/science/sciencenow/la-sci-sn-cte-head-hits-20180118-story.html “Concussion Not Needed to Trigger CTE in Brain,” HealthDay on WebMD, Jan. 18. https://www.webmd.com/brain/news/20180118/concussion-not-needed-to-triggercte-in-brain#1
Chicago had 2x cancels vs nation in 2016.  Reported 3% decline in 2017

This is a completely speculative guess as I have no idea how many kids actually play football... My kids will not play and yours shouldn't either.  There is a strong argument that even watching football is immoral.  Aside from the physical/mental impact, it is a tool of exploitation and oppression against the lower socioeconomic strata.
Concussions + less 2nd generation born Americans (declining growth rate) = less opportunity and less participation

I think that CTE  happens in nearly every contact sport out there more than we suspect, and we are just beginning to see the tip of the iceberg on this information regarding CTE. There should be more studies done on all contact sports, regardless of what medium is hitting the head (Example soccer ball to the head) any sport can be a potential for CTE.   The long term ramifications to CTE on treatment, medications,  including Dementia care at earlier age when you can no longer care for yourself should be discussed with every parent and child that is interested in contact sports, and it should come from not only their physicians, but the whole sporting industry in an effort to reduce the potentially life altering long term effects from CTE.  Alzheimer's/Dementia is a devastating illness regardless whether its from fatty plagues or repeated head trauma. We are unprepared even now with all the current information we have on Alzheimer's/Dementia, limited medical options/funding, so it comes down to a personal decision to not play a sport that could impact you even before you can vote, marry, see the world.

I suspect that high school football involvement will stay the same in the face of increasing high school student populations. That suggests a downward per 1000 students trend. I believe that football popularity will decrease as the repercussions of head trauma become better understood.
Enrollment is likely to decline again and if it follows recent trends should be right around the 1.03 million mark.
As the evidence continues to mount concerning the medium- and long-term dangers of playing football the pressure will continue to mount to curtail HS football programs in general.

The 2016 season was at 1057382 players. The greatest gain ever was 133,622 players year to year in 1973. But they mention in the mid 70's that they changed their counting method. So the max gain would be 61959 if you cut those years off, in '85. Go Bears. Max loss is -88129 in '79. Max 32773 and Min -28458 if you start from the 90's If you don't break from 26 years of data, then starting from 1057382+32773 and 1057382-28458 which gives me a range of 1090155-1028924. This looks a lot like the spread they've given us, so not helpful yet.  Seven of the last eight years have been losses. So if we err towards the range of loss, we can cut our possible outcomes in half. Here's a five number summary on all losses from 90's onward: Minimum: -28458
Quartile Q1: -11032.5
Median: -3560
Quartile Q3: -1880.5
Maximum: -66 -28458	1057382	1028924
-11032.5	1057382	1046349.5
-3560	1057382	1053822
-1880.5	1057382	1055501.5
-66	1057382	1057316 I don't want to predict the worst year ever. I'm going to stack up on 1046349.5 - 1055501.5 but leave room for others.
Probably already declined as much as it is going to.
1,059,399 current, media and downward trend would suggest a decline of around 23000

Big question I want answered is what was the decrease for the freshman class? Did parents/kids pull/leave after being on the team, or was the freshman class disproportionately less than the other years? If it was, then I'd suspect we could see a similar decrease. Comparing stats on Baseball and Football: From 2015 to 2017 the number of schools w/ baseball increased .50% and players 1.05%; the number of schools w/ football decreased 0.39% and players 2.43%
Data I found show the current number is 1,085,000 and the trend is up

last year was a big decline, but even before then there was a steady decline in the rate. However, some years saw a slight rise, so there is some noise in the series, and given last year's big drop some could be reversed (thus the probability of > 1.06)

From all the previous years the numbers have hovered in the 1,080,000 - 1,100,000 range (though school population increased during that time so percentage decline I'd guess). Is a chance the dip is permanent due to negative press or just students going into other sports, but I think could be around the same figure or somewhat higher barring stories on a considerable number of high schools stopping football to make me update to a much lower figure.
Historical trends, recent research on CTE and increased press on the issue.

More parents and students are becoming increasingly aware of the dangers from head hits in football.  Recent research particularly notes dangers for kids age 12 and younger. High school, college and pro players also face brain-injury risks. Related news reports and OSINT: “Youth tackle football declining amid health concerns,” CBS, Sept. 20. https://www.cbsnews.com/news/youth-tackle-football-declining-health-concerns/ “New Study Links Playing Youth Football to Later Brain Damage,” TIME magazine, Sept. 19. http://time.com/4948320/football-brain-damage-consussions-study/ “Playing Tackle Football Before 12 Is Tied to Brain Problems Later,” New York Times, Sept. 19. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/19/sports/football/tackle-football-brain-youth.html “‘The Future of Detecting Brain Damage in Football,” The Atlantic, Sept. 21. https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2017/09/football-brain-injury-chronic-traumatic-encephalopathy/540459/

Data suggests students are finding their way into other sports, such as soccer and track & field. Press is extremely negative and early indications from local programs for high school age children in some of the larger participation states such as California (http://www.sacbee.com/sports/article168124977.html) and Illinois (http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-football-youth-decline-met-20170904-story.html) are not good - many are experiencing reduced numbers or being cancelled altogether. However, NCES projected increases in school enrollment in Texas (most participants, 14%) and Florida (3rd, 15%) may offset some of the decline seen as a result of the CTE concerns and other negative press (stats from https://nces.ed.gov/programs/coe/pdf/coe_cga.pdf).
some high school camps and workshops, and neck devices cropping up that purport to offer 'safe' collisions getting strong attendance.

Last year, participation droped by 23K. Assuming the same drop, we get 1,034,000.  So I put most of the weight in that bin. The news has been getting worse here...it is more in the press, and the recent disclosure about Hernandez created a memory impression. I would expect the numbers to be around that estimate.
another 2% decline seems like the most reasonable outcome at this time.

2010-2011: 1,109,836
2011-2012: 1,097,597
2012-2013: 1,088,158
2013-2014: 1,094,949
2014-2015: 1,085,182
2015-2016: 1,082,637
2016-2017: 1,059,399 The numbers took a tumble last year (only 2.2%), but high school football is an important community affair in some parts of the country. And I don't know how much of this information about damage to high school players from routine hits is getting to parents and students. I think people understand the dangers of concussions, but I'm not sure about CTE.  I'll just guess the same amount of decline as last year (to 1,036,660).  Texas participation among boys increased from 2015/2016 to 2016/2017, from 163,835 to 163,992. California for 2015/2016 was 100,205 and 97,079 for 2016/2017. I note California and Texas because they have the highest participation. California is down more than Texas is up, but I think this indicates that different parts of the country feel differently about the risks involved in football.
Last year had a steep dropoff and the news for football only got worse this year, so an at least similarly steep dropoff might be expected.

If I cared more about this Q I'd do some demographics, because this answer is affected not only by the current and recent past numbers of participants, but also by the size of the current and incoming high school classes, including where they live.  If they all live in New Hampshire, nobody will play football.  If they all live in Mississippi, nobody won't.  These numbers are available, of course, but torpor reigns here just now.

Another decline of approx 20 percent this year, following a 20 percent drop last year, seems probable due to concerns about brain injury and CTE. Also, this trend could increase, raising the percentage drop to more than 20 percent. Related information and OSINT in the news: “Head Injury and Chronic Brain Damage: It’s Complicated,” Scientific American, Sept. 1. https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/head-injury-and-chronic-brain-damage-it-rsquo-s-complicated/ “Mother whose son had CTE warns young athletes of disease,” KCCI 8 TV (Des Moines, Iowa), Aug. 26. http://www.kcci.com/article/mom-whose-son-had-cte-heeds-warning-among-young-athletes/12097665 “Is concussion research causing a decline in football participation?” MultiBriefs, Aug. 31. http://exclusive.multibriefs.com/content/is-concussion-research-causing-a-decline-in-football-participation/mailto

Comment by user CubsWin alerted me that I was using total football participation, rather than 11-man, which was 1,057,000 in 2016-2017, so I need to adjust my forecast numbers, although the analysis is largely the same.  Just dropping at same rate as the prior year would put new # at 1,030,000. I see some evidence to support an acceleration in participation decline, but not a massive one. I see more than just concussions driving this issue. There are just other options available now. Points to a slow decline and death by a thousand cuts. Concussions feel like a  issue that "educated" people worry about and thus gets reported on, but doesn't actually resonate with most people. Those are the people whose children play HS football. The other kids already play other sports.  What would cause quick decline would be government action, if poorly received. No sign of appetite for that currently though

Just dropping at same rate would put new # at 1,060,000. Probably safe to forecast a larger decrease than last year, but not by much I see more than just concussions driving this issue. There are just other options available now. Points to a slow decline and death by a thousand cuts. Concussions feel like an issue that "educated" people worry about and thus gets reported on, but doesn't actually resonate with most people whose children play HS football. The other kids already play other sports.  What would cause quick decline would be government action, if poorly received. No sign of appetite for that currently though.

According to the stats provided by GJ and National Federation of State High School Associations, participation dropped by about 20,000 from 2015-16 school year to 2016-17 school year.  That compares to significantly smaller declines of a few thousand steadily from 2013-14, 2014-15 and 2015-16 school years. So, the trend of declining participation seems to be increasing, notably in last year's school year from the year before. Undoubtedly the continuing news and education (and even movies) about CTE is getting through.  Stats on kids younger than high-school age are significant to track also. Some brain experts say football head hits before age 14 can do even more damage due to incomplete myelin sheath protective formation around brain nerves. Society is slowly changing about tackle football. Parents of boys who play or are interested in playing football should be paying attention. Flag football provides a good substitute.  Related news articles and OSINT on this important topic: “Football or basketball? In age of CTE and AAU, it’s a tough call for players, parents,” Washington Post, Aug. 30. https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/football-or-basketball-in-age-of-cte-and-aau-its-a-tough-call-for-players-parents/2017/08/30/24840a24-8cc7-11e7-a2b0-e68cbf0b1f19_story.html?utm_term=.cd22c5f20310 “ESPN Football Analyst Walks Away, Disturbed by Brain Trauma on Field,” New York Times, Aug. 30. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/30/sports/espn-ed-cunningham-football-concussions.html “I don't think I can watch football anymore,” Chicago Tribune, Aug. 30. http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/opinion/chapman/ct-perspec-chapman-football-brain-injury-0831-story.html “Football’s enjoyment is on a fade pattern,” Washington Post, Sept. 1. https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/americas-waning-romance-with-football/2017/09/01/5e26a344-8e7b-11e7-91d5-ab4e4bb76a3a_story.html?utm_term=.4791dd971460

It's worth looking at the trends of the past years and to see the slight decline:
2012-13: 1,086,627
2013-14: 1,093,234
2014-15: 1,083,617
2015-16: 1,080,693
2016-17: 1,057,382

This is America.  We admire people who either administer or acquire permanent injuries, brain damage and even death, as long as we can describe them as heroes and get somebody else to pay the costs.  A few thousand parents will pay attention to the news and shift the kids over to lacrosse or trombone, but overall the numbers will stay high as long as we continue to pretend that (a) this game requires athletic ability beyond beating up members of an opposite sex, and (b) our personal kid has a high probability of a long and lucrative NFL career.  Kinda makes you proud, huh?
